channel.title: Maurice Vellacott
channel.description: Recent news about Maurice Vellacott, from openparliament.ca.

item.title: Mentioned by Macleans.ca
item.description:
Au revoir (eventually), Maurice Vellacott
Late last week, Conservative MP Maurice Vellacott announced that he will retire when the next election is called. When he departs, the Conservative caucus will lose one of its most prominent social conservatives. Campaign Life Coalition president Jim ...

item.title: Mentioned by The Catholic Register
item.description:
Pro-life MP Maurice Vellacott not running in next election
Photo by Deborah Gyapong. OTTAWA - Veteran pro-life MP Maurice Vellacott has announced he will not seek a seventh term in the House of Commons in the next federal election. Vellacott, a Conservative, chaired the Parliamentary Pro-life Caucus for 10 ...

item.title: Mentioned by Lifesite
item.description:
Pro-life MP Maurice Vellacott will not seek re-election
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan, July 26, 2013 (LifeSiteNews.com) - Staunchly pro-life MP Maurice Vellacott has announced that he won't run in the 2015 federal election, citing family concerns and a desire to pursue other interests. “After much deliberation, I have come to the decision that now is the right time to pass the torch,” Vellacott said. "At the time of the next election, I'll be 60 years young, and in my 19th year as a Member of Parliament." Vellacott has been the MP for Saskatoon-Wanuskewin for six terms, since ...

item.title: Mentioned by Post
item.description:
Maurice vellacott won't seek re-election - Regina Leader
Saskatoon MP Maurice Vellacott is not running in the next federal election, but until then the controversial Conservative will continue to speak his mind. Vellacott, now in his sixth term as Saskatoon-Wanuskewin MP, has rarely shied away from entering ...

item.title: Mentioned by Victoria Times Colonist
item.description:
Longtime Saskatchewan member of Parliament says he won't run for office again
Saskatoon-Wanuskewin MP Maurice Vellacott says he won't run in the next election because he wants to spend more time with his family, including one son in his 20s who has significant mental health challenges. Vellacott also says it's the "appropriate thing ...
